citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
One pig was observed with an abnormally long outside lateral hoof. . Excessively long hooves can cause the animal
discomfort and can contribute to potential lameness. The licensee must establish a program with the attending
veterinarian to ensure the use of appropriate methods to prevent and control diseases and injuries. The licensee must
correct this issue.
********Correct by August 18, 2025

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A dog "Sophie" was observed in an abnormally thin body condition. The ribs and the spine vertebrae were obvious, and
the pelvic bones and all other bony structures were obvious and prominent. The weight loss had not been previously
communicated to the attending veterinarian. Various conditions could cause an animal to lose weight, such as illness,
parasites, etc. Abnormal health issues must be communicated to the attending veterinarian in a timely fashion, so that
appropriate veterinary care can be offered to the animal. The licensee must contact the attending veterinarian in order to
obtain care for this dog.
******Correct by August 7, 2025

Several of the dog enclosures had an excessive buildup of debris and grime on the doors and walls. There was areas of
rust observed on the bottom of several of the chain link metal enclosure doors. A collection of clutter was observed, as
well an overall layer of dust and grime through the area. These conditions can affect the health and wellbeing of the dogs
and could possibly lead to illness. Cleaning of surfaces and areas in housing facilities must be performed as often as
necessary to satisfy generally accepted standards and husbandry.
********Correct by August 18, 2025

Medical records are not being maintained by the licensee for the dogs at the facility. Medical records must contain
required information such as the identity of the animal, names and dates of vaccines and administered, and dates and
findings/results of all screening, routine, or otherwise required or recommended tests or examination. The licensee must
maintain records for dogs held at the facility and they must be made available for APHIS inspection. The licensee must
correct this issue.
*********Correct by September 1, 2025

1. The barn door in the camel enclosure had fallen off on of the hinges, creating a large gap between the door and the
wall. This could cause harm to the animals if they were to become lodged in the gap. The housing facilities must be kept
in good repair. The facility must correct this issue.
2. Several areas of the chain link fencing for the sheep enclosure was observed to be sagging downwards. In addition, the
shelter for the sheep is a metal building, and multiple areas are observed to be jagged at the bottom. Several sheep were
observed to be laying down with their backs against this portion of the metal. This could cause injury to the animals. The
facility must be kept in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury.

The water receptacle for the yak was not being cleaned at a frequency which prevented the growth of algae . Drinking
water with algae could cause the animal to become ill. Water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitary. The licensee
must correct this issue.
*******Correct by August 8, 2025

The facility has multiple areas of accumulating trash, construction debris and material. Several of these areas are directly
adjacent to enclosures housing animals. This could lead to pests, vermin infestation, and possibly spread disease to the
animals. Premises shall be kept clean in order to protect the animals. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in
designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals. The facility must correct this issue.
********Correct by September 15, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
One pig was observed with an abnormally long outside lateral hoof. . Excessively long hooves can cause the animal 
discomfort and can contribute to potential lameness. The licensee must establish a program with the attending 
veterinarian to ensure the use of appropriate methods to prevent and control diseases and injuries. The licensee must 
correct this issue.  
********Correct by August 18, 2025 
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A dog "Sophie" was observed in an abnormally thin body condition. The ribs and the spine vertebrae were obvious, and 
the pelvic bones and all other bony structures were obvious and prominent. The weight loss had not been previously 
communicated to the attending veterinarian. Various conditions could cause an animal to lose weight, such as illness, 
parasites, etc. Abnormal health issues must be communicated to the attending veterinarian in a timely fashion, so that 
appropriate veterinary care can be offered to the animal. The licensee must contact the attending veterinarian in order to 
obtain care for this dog.  
******Correct by August 7, 2025 
3.1(c)(3) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Several of the dog enclosures had an excessive buildup of debris and grime on the doors and walls. There was areas of 
rust observed on the bottom of several of the chain link metal enclosure doors. A collection of clutter was observed, as 
well an overall layer of dust and grime through the area. These conditions can affect the health and wellbeing of the dogs 
and could possibly lead to illness. Cleaning of surfaces and areas in housing facilities must be performed as often as 
necessary to satisfy generally accepted standards and husbandry. 
********Correct by August 18, 2025 
3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs.

Medical records are not being maintained by the licensee for the dogs at the facility. Medical records must contain 
required information such as the identity of the animal, names and dates of vaccines and administered, and dates and 
findings/results of all screening, routine, or otherwise required or recommended tests or examination. The licensee must 
maintain records for dogs held at the facility and they must be made available for APHIS inspection. The licensee must 
correct this issue. 
*********Correct by September 1, 2025 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
1. The barn door in the camel enclosure had fallen off on of the hinges, creating a large gap between the door and the 
wall. This could cause harm to the animals if they were to become lodged in the gap. The housing facilities must be kept 
in good repair. The facility must correct this issue.  
2. Several areas of the chain link fencing for the sheep enclosure was observed to be sagging downwards. In addition, the 
shelter for the sheep is a metal building, and multiple areas are observed to be jagged at the bottom. Several sheep were 
observed to be laying down with their backs against this portion of the metal. This could cause injury to the animals. The 
facility must be kept in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury. 
3.130 
   
Watering. 
The water receptacle for the yak was not being cleaned at a frequency which prevented the growth of algae . Drinking 
water with algae could cause the animal to become ill. Water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitary. The licensee 
must correct this issue.  
*******Correct by August 8, 2025 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The facility has multiple areas of accumulating trash, construction debris and material. Several of these areas are directly 
adjacent to enclosures housing animals. This could lead to pests, vermin infestation, and possibly spread disease to the 
animals. Premises shall be kept clean in order to protect the animals. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in 
designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals. The facility must correct this issue. 
********Correct by September 15, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
